title: Fed Prepares Second Rate Cut to Cushion Against Global Risks
text:
The Federal Reserve is likely to cut its short-term benchmark rate by one quarter percentage point to a range between 1.75% and 2% at the conclusion of its two-day meeting on Wednesday. The big question is what kind of clues the central bank offers about any more rate reductions.

Hints could be provided in the Fed’s new policy statement and economic projections, to be released at 2 p.m. EDT, and at Chairman Jerome Powell ’s press conference at 2:30 p.m. Here’s what to watch:

The Outlook

Officials cited three reasons—weakening global growth, rising trade policy uncertainty and muted inflation—for cutting rates at their July 30-31 meeting and are likely to do so again this week. The U.S.-China trade war worsened immediately after the July meeting, and the global industrial downturn shows no sign of bottoming out. Both point to another cut this week.

Officials expected the U.S. economy to slow this year, but increased uncertainty means officials aren’t sure if the economy is going to cool a little bit or a lot.

U.S. economic data paint a mixed picture. Consumer spending has been solid, but manufacturing has weakened. Recent revisions to employment and profit growth shows the economy over the past year wasn’t as strong as previously thought.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS What are you hoping comes out of this meeting? Join the conversation below.

The Dot Plot

Because the rate cut is expected, attention will quickly move to the quarterly interest-rate projections, the so-called dot plot, and Mr. Powell’s press conference.

As in the past, the dot plot remains a potential source of confusion. The projection of rate cuts for 2019 carries added significance because there are only two meetings left this year, meaning it provides a strong indication of officials’ expected near-term policy path.

In June, seven of 17 officials penciled in two rate cuts this year. Having delivered those cuts now, the big question is how many of them will project at least one more rate reduction this year.

It’s possible that at least eight participants will project a third cut this year, which would represent the median expectation. It seems equally possible that a substantial minority will pencil in another cut.

Mr. Powell has warned repeatedly this year against reading too much into the dots and could do so again if the median projection seems out of step with his overarching message.

Questions and Answers

Mr. Powell puzzled some investors at his July press conference when he characterized the rate cut as a “mid-cycle adjustment” instead of the start of the kind of “long cutting cycle” the Fed adopts in a recession.

His phrase was intended to draw parallels to two separate episodes in 1995 and 1998 when the Fed cut rates three times over several months and avoided recession. But some listeners took it to mean the Fed might be done cutting rates or that it was underestimating the severity of the potential slowdown.

Mr. Powell has since steered clear of repeating the phrase and seems unlikely to repeat it again on Wednesday. But his broader point hasn’t much changed: Officials don’t think they are in a recession-fighting stance that would entail a longer, aggressive series of cuts.

Investors will want clues about how long the rate cuts could go on. Because officials have little experience dealing with a trade war, they may not offer much specificity.

Committee Tensions

The degree of consensus or division on the committee will also help shape expectations about the rate outlook.

Mr. Powell faced resistance to the July rate cut from around half of the Fed’s 12 reserve bank presidents. Two of them with a vote on the rate-setting committee—Boston’s Eric Rosengren and Kansas City’s Esther George —dissented then in favor of holding rates steady because they didn’t think the U.S. economy needed the extra boost. Because the economy hasn’t deteriorated since then, they could vote Wednesday against another rate cut.

Meantime, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said two weeks ago in an interview he would support cutting rates by a larger half-point because of a sharp fall in market-determined rates since the last meeting. This suggests he might vote Wednesday against a quarter-point reduction.

Some bond investors say a larger cut, by weakening the dollar and boosting expectations of future inflation, would deliver more convincing evidence that the Fed was committed to lift inflation more rapidly to its 2% target.

Most Fed officials haven’t been swayed by these arguments. Several worry it could look panicky and would encourage markets to demand or expect more stimulus.

Cash Crunch

The New York Fed injected cash into money markets on Tuesday and planned to do so again Wednesday after overnight rates spiked due to technical factors, including declines in bank reserves held at the Fed.

The rate volatility creates urgency for the Fed to resolve longstanding questions over a set of complex monetary plumbing issues.

Officials ended their portfolio runoff last month, but they haven’t said when they will allow their asset holdings to grow in step with demand for their liabilities, which include currency in circulation. Until then, the amount of money banks hold at the Fed—called reserves—will continue to decline.

They could allow their portfolio to grow again by purchasing a small amount of Treasurys every month to end the slow decline in reserves.

They could cut the interest rate paid to banks on excess reserves, something they have done three times in the past to increase liquidity in other short-term lending markets.

They could also become more involved in supporting money markets by creating a new standing facility that would reduce volatility in participants’ demand for cash. Officials debated creating a facility in June but didn’t reach a final decision.
